home.title: Web Accessibility Practical Guide
home.lead: Accessibility means ensuring a web that's usable by everyone: people with disabilities, seniors, mobile users, slow connections, broken arm, noisy environments, etc.

stats.disability: of the world's population lives with a disability

curbCut.title: When we design for disability, we solve problems everyone encounters
curbCut.intro1: Curb cuts revolutionized cities for wheelchairs, but also for all pedestrians with suitcases, strollers, or bikes.
curbCut.intro2: An improvement for some benefits everyone. This concept, born from street access ramps, applies perfectly to the web.
curbCut.imageCaption: Typical example of a curb cut

ramps.title: Curb cuts
ramps.benefitsAlso: Parents with strollers, cyclists, delivery workers with hand trucks, people with rolling suitcases, skateboards, scooters, elderly people

captions.title: Video captions
captions.designedFor: Deaf or hard of hearing people
captions.benefitsAlso: Watching videos on the subway, learning a foreign language, following a conference in a noisy environment, understanding difficult accents

keyboard.title: Keyboard navigation
keyboard.designedFor: People who cannot use a mouse
keyboard.benefitsAlso: Developers using shortcuts, users with broken mouse, power users preferring keyboard, people with arm in cast

voice.title: Smartphone voice control
voice.designedFor: Blind people and people with motor disabilities
voice.benefitsAlso: Messaging while driving, sports with headphones, hands busy with tools, remote control, multitasking at the office

toothbrush.title: Electric toothbrush
toothbrush.designedFor: People with reduced mobility or arthritis (1954)
toothbrush.benefitsAlso: Better brushing for everyone, recommended by dentists, children learning, tired people, proven superior efficiency

audiobooks.title: Audiobooks
audiobooks.designedFor: Blind people (1932, American Foundation for the Blind)
audiobooks.benefitsAlso: Drivers, joggers, multitasking, dyslexics, children learning to read, $1.3 billion in sales in 2020

curbCut.quote: Accessibility is not a constraint, it's innovation in disguise.

ariaComponents.title: ARIA
ariaComponents.description: Enrich the semantics of complex components to make them accessible

whatIsAria.title: What is ARIA?
whatIsAria.intro: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) is a W3C specification that allows improving the accessibility of rich web applications and dynamic components.

q1.title: What is web accessibility?
q1.content: Web accessibility means making websites and applications usable by everyone, including people with disabilities.

q2.title: Why is it important?
q2.content: 15% of the world's population lives with a disability (Source: United Nations). Accessibility improves the experience for everyone and is often a legal obligation.

q3.title: How to get started?
q3.content: Start by learning the WCAG guidelines, use audit tools, and test with real users.

forms.title: Forms with ARIA attributes
forms.explanation: ARIA attributes enrich forms by providing labels, descriptions and states to assistive technologies.

accordion.title: Accessible accordion
accordion.explanation: An accordion must use appropriate ARIA attributes, support keyboard navigation and announce state changes.

tabindex.title: Tabindex and keyboard navigation
tabindex.intro: The tabindex attribute controls whether an element can receive keyboard focus and in what order.

dropdown.title: Accessible dropdown menu
dropdown.explanation: A dropdown menu must support keyboard navigation, close with Escape, and maintain focus appropriately.

gallery.title: Accessible image gallery
gallery.explanation: An image gallery must allow keyboard navigation and provide contextual descriptions for each image. The ARIA tablist/tab/tabpanel pattern is perfect for this use case.

sortableTable.explanation: A sortable table must indicate the current sort state, allow keyboard navigation, and announce changes to screen readers.

liveRegions.title: Dynamic aria-live regions
liveRegions.explanation: Aria-live regions allow announcing content changes to screen readers. 'polite' waits for the current announcement to finish, 'assertive' interrupts immediately.

iconButtons.explanation: Buttons that contain only icons must have an aria-label or visually hidden text to be understood by screen readers.

combobox.explanation: A search with suggestions (combobox) must be keyboard navigable, announce results and allow selection.

tabindex.title: Tabindex and keyboard navigation
tabindex.intro: The tabindex attribute controls whether an element can receive keyboard focus and in what order.

positive.title: ✅ tabindex="0"
positive.description: Element is focusable in the natural DOM order

negative.title: ⚠️ tabindex="-1"
negative.description: Focusable by JavaScript but not by Tab

bestPractices.title: 📋 Tabindex best practices
bestPractices.practice1: Use tabindex="0" to make custom interactive elements focusable
bestPractices.practice2: Use tabindex="-1" for programmatic focus (modals, alerts)
bestPractices.practice3: NEVER use positive values - respect DOM order
bestPractices.practice4: Native interactive elements (<button>, <a>, <input>) don't need tabindex

textContrast.title: Text contrast
textContrast.explanation: WCAG AA contrast ratio requires a minimum of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (18pt+ or 14pt+ bold). AAA level is stricter with 7:1 and 4.5:1.

good.sample2: Black text on white (21:1) - AAA Pass
good.sample3: Dark blue text on white (5.9:1) - AA Pass
good.sample4: White on dark blue (8.6:1) - AAA Pass
good.sample5: White on black background (21:1) - AAA Pass

colorblind.explanation: About 8% of men and 0.5% of women are colorblind. Red-green combinations are particularly problematic.

motion.title: Respecting motion preferences
motion.explanation: Users can configure their system to reduce animations. This preference must be respected to avoid nausea and distractions.

zoom.title: Zoom and large font size support
zoom.explanation: The interface must remain functional and readable up to 200% zoom. Texts must adapt to the user's font size preferences.

responsive.title: Adaptive and responsive design
responsive.explanation: The interface must work on all devices and orientations, with appropriately sized controls for touch.

lazyLoading.title: Lazy Loading: load only visible resources
lazyLoading.explanation: Lazy loading (deferred loading) allows loading images and resources only when the user needs them, rather than downloading everything at once when the page loads.

bad.heading: Load everything at once (Eager Loading)
bad.problem: Concrete example: An e-commerce site with 50 products loads all images immediately, even those at the bottom of the page that the user may never see.
bad.term: Technical term: Eager Loading = immediate loading of all resources

issues.problem1: Problem 1: 50 images × 200 KB = 10 MB downloaded immediately
issues.problem2: Problem 2: 8-15 second wait time before seeing the page
issues.problem3: Problem 3: Unnecessarily consumes mobile data allowance
issues.problem4: Problem 4: Stresses the processor and drains battery

resources.img3: Image 3 at bottom of page (200 KB)
resources.img4: Image 4 at bottom of page (200 KB)
resources.img5: Image 5 at bottom of page (200 KB)

good.heading: Progressive loading (Lazy Loading + Cache)
good.solution: Concrete example: The same e-commerce site first loads visible content, then subsequent images only when the user scrolls.
good.terms: Technical terms: Lazy Loading = deferred loading • HTTP Cache = browser temporary memory

cache.label: HTTP Cache enabled
cache.description: Stores in memory to avoid re-downloading (Cache-Control)

speed.label: Speed (FCP)
speed.description: Faster First Contentful Paint = page visible immediately

mobile.label: Mobile data
mobile.description: Essential for users with limited data plan or slow network (3G)

battery.label: Battery
battery.description: Less network transfer = significant energy savings

devices.label: Old devices
devices.description: Fewer resources to process = works on old hardware

motion.autoCarousel: Carousel that scrolls automatically without stop option

semanticHtml.title: Semantic HTML
semanticHtml.description: Use the right HTML elements to structure content in an understandable way

pageStructure.title: Page structure
pageStructure.explanation: A clear semantic structure helps screen readers navigate and understand content. Sectioning elements (header, nav, main, footer) create important landmarks.

headings.title: Heading hierarchy
headings.explanation: A logical heading hierarchy (h1 → h2 → h3) allows screen readers to create a navigation outline and users to understand the content structure.

buttonsVsLinks.title: Buttons vs clickable elements
buttonsVsLinks.explanation: Use the right elements for actions: buttons for actions, links for navigation. This ensures proper semantics and expected keyboard behaviors.

lists.title: Lists and structured data
lists.explanation: Using appropriate list elements allows screen readers to announce the number of items and facilitate navigation.
